author: wired staff
text: americans spend 77 minutes a day managing voicemail, cell phone, pager, and email messages, but 52 percent insist that these technologies reduce stress levels (yankelovich partners)  ... seventy-nine percent of women business owners surveyed said they worried about getting adequate access to technology (national foundation for women business owners) ... almost one-third of television viewers say they switch on the tube not for its quality programming but to keep themselves company (arbitron) ... sesame street is aired on public television more than any other show, topping the news hour with jim lehrer, in second place, and barney & friends, a close third (corporation for public broadcasting) ... when starting up their machines for the first time, one in five new pc owners faces hardware or software glitches that require technical support (windows magazine) ... twenty-one percent of news stories about corporations present a positive spin that could persuade audiences to buy the company's products (the delahaye group) ... some 4.6 million net users have applied for a loan or credit card online (cyber dialogue) ... bankruptcy has increased 19 percent since 1996, with 96 percent of filings non-business related (american bankruptcy institute) ... one in five television commercials now displays a url (response marketing group) ... one-fourth of new-car buyers in the us consult auto sites on the web (jd power and associates) ... ecommerce sales will hit $1 trillion by 2005 (organization for economic development and cooperation) ... by 2002, 16 million us homes will have high-speed cable modems; cable companies will provide 80 percent of broadband net connections (forrester research) ... seventy-seven percent of americans believe the net improves grades and is a necessary tool for academic success (at&t) ... sixty-three percent of americans want to eliminate bilingual education (the gallup poll) ... last year, americans filled 2.78 billion prescriptions - 11 for every man, woman, and child;
